awd_titl_txt: Numerical Spectral Study of Elliptic Operators
awd_abstract_narration:
Since Lord Rayleigh conjectured more than a century ago that the disk should minimize the first Laplace-Dirichlet eigenvalue among all shapes of equal area, spectral study of elliptic operators has been an active research topic with applications including mechanical vibration, optical resonators, photonic crystals, and population dynamics. In mechanical vibration, for example, it is interesting to explore what shapes or what density distributions can generate minimal fundamental frequency; in photonic crystals, one seeks to design semiconductor structures with a periodic variation of refractive index to maximize photonic bandgap in which the propagation of light is forbidden. This project aims to advance numerical approaches to these kinds of questions for classes of eigenvalue problems that arise in design of containers to minimize fluid sloshing and in vibration control. Researchers have turned their attention to these questions with a renewed interest due to surprising recent discoveries, which include symmetry structure found in the optimizer of Steklov eigenvalue problems, optimal density arrangements in thin plates, and localization of vibration induced by interior clamped points. The project will explore a range of related open questions and aims to develop numerical approaches to solve them. The project also provides opportunities for mentoring students and engaging interested scientists, including those from underrepresented groups.  Results are expected to have important potential application in systems that reduce liquid sloshing in missiles and other vessels, in noise and vibration control, and in medical and geophysical imaging.
   
This project aims to develop numerical approaches to solve Steklov and biharmonic eigenvalue problems and study their related shape and topology optimization problems. The forward solvers for this project are based on boundary integral methods, finite element methods, and spectral methods. The optimization solvers are based on shape/topology derivatives and rearrangement methods. The investigator will study a wide range of problems arising from applications in liquid sloshing and plate vibrations, including (1) computation of the k-th Steklov eigenvalue problem and its optimization among star-shaped domains in three dimensions, (2) computation of principal eigenvalue of mixed Steklov eigenvalue problems and its related shape optimization, (3) Steklov eigenvalue problems on general manifolds, (4) spectral study of buckled plate eigenvalue problems, (5) localization of eigenfunctions induced by clamped points, and (6) multiphase shape optimization problems involving biharmonic operators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: 

This project leads to the development of robust numerical schemes for solving eigenvalue problems of partial differential equations, their related shape optimization problems, and the derivation of theoretical properties of the optimal shapes. The algorithms have been applied to interesting problems arising in biology and physics, including (1) spectral methods based on conformal mappings to solve the Steklov eigenvalue problem and its related shape optimization problems (2) maximizing the gap-to-midgap ratio for the spectral gap over the class of potentials for periodic Schrodinger operators, (3) minimization of the first nonzero eigenvalue problem for two-phase conductors with Neumann boundary conditions, (4) shape identification and evolution in medical and biological applications, (5) computation of free boundary minimal surfaces via extremal Steklov eigenvalue problems, (6) computing eigenmodes of elliptic operators on manifolds, (7) rearrangement methods for the Poisson's equation for different boundary conditions, (8) optimal chemotherapy and radiotherapy for brain tumor growth in a reaction-diffusion model, (9) optimization problems of inhomogeneous rods and plates, (9) spectral study of buckled plate eigenvalue problems, and (10) optimization problem involving p-Laplacian operator. 

 

Broader Impacts:

The numerical methods and theoretical approaches have been applied to a wide range of applications including liquid sloshing, control of mechanical vibration, elasticity, photonic crystal, population dynamics, optimal chemotherapy, and optimal radiotherapy. The PI has made her research results including publications and codes available on her personal website, journal article website (via supplementary materials), and cloud-based data repositories such as Mendeley Data and Zenodo. The PI has developed several undergraduate curriculums, including linear algebra with computing, ordinary differential equations, partial differential equations, advanced topics in mathematics on image processing, and numerical analysis by incorporating programing skills, developing visualization tools, and assigning final projects with real-world applications and/or research topics. To broaden the dissemination and enhance scientific and technological understanding, the PI organized minisymposium sessions at AIMS Conference, SIAM meeting, and SMB annual meeting. In addition, she served as an organizing committee member for SMB 2021 annual meeting which has more than 2500 participants, the SMB Education & REU workshop, and international conference on new trends in scientific computing at IPAM, UCLA. To engage underrepresented groups and students at different levels, she organized applied math seminars and working group seminar, served as a panelist for the AWM workshop to provide her perspectives and advice as a woman in math research at the SIAM annual meeting, delivered a talk at a Hackathon workshop, and engaged high school students in a session hosted by the Johns Hopkins Center for Talented Youth Family Academic Programs, Science and Technology Series. This project also led to the training of students at different levels including several Ph.D. students and undergraduate students.
